titleStmt.title: TO MY EVER most worthily honour'd Lord, the Earle of NORVVICH.
titleStmt.author: Exon, Joseph

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: TO MY EVER most worthily honour'd Lord, the Earle of NORVVICH.
analytic.author: Exon, Joseph

monogr.title: The hypocrite : Set forth in a sermon at the court; February, 28. 1629. Being the third Sunday in Lent [sic] By Ios: Exon
monogr.author: Hall, Joseph

div.head: TO MY EVER most worthily honour'd Lord, the Earle of NORVVICH.
div.p:
I Might not but tell the world, that this Sermon which was mine in the Pulpit, is Yours in the Presse; your Lordships will (which shall neuer bee other then a command
to mee) fetches it forth into the Light before the fellowes. Let mee bee branded with the Title of it, if I can thinke it worthy of the publike view, in comparison of many acurate peeces of others, which I see content themselues dayly to dye in the eare. Howsoeuer, if it may doe good, I shall blesse your Lordship for helping to aduance my gaine.

Your noble and sincere true-heartednesse to your God, your King, your
Countrey, your friend, is so well knowne, that it can be no disparagement to your Lordship to patronize this Hypocrite; whose very inscription might cast a blurr vpon some guilty reputation. Goe on still (most noble Lord) to be a great Example of vertue and fidelity to an hollow and vntrusty Age: You shall not want either the acclamations or Prayers of

closer.signed: Your Lordships euer deuoted in all true duty, and obseruance. IOS. Exon.
